reviewText: Have you ever known someone who was obsessed with sports, so much so that it started to interfere with his personal life? If you have, then you can probably relate to this movie, "Fever Pitch", a film about a guy who falls for a woman and seems to have his personal life on track only to find his fanaticism with baseball getting in the way of his relationship.This movie is centered in Boston and the lead character, played by Jimmy Fallon, is hooked on the Red Sox. He has season tickets and never misses a game, not for anything. But now, he has met a woman he likes and he has to make choices. Exactly how important is baseball to him? Is it so important that he would choose it over the desires of the woman in his life? The decision isn't as easy as it sounds, for Fallon's love affair with the Red Sox is very deep and very real.There are some things I really like about this film. First of all, I like the fact that Drew Barrymore, Fallon's love interest, doesn't get all negative toward him and his interest in the Red Sox. She wants him to enjoy the things he likes best. But she does get a little impatient after a while- and understandably so- when she realizes just how crazy Fallon is for his beloved baseball team. He does end up choosing baseball over her on more than one occasion and it almost ruins the relationship. This film does a decent job in helping to answer some important questions about how much is too much when it comes to extracurricular activities.On the negative side, however, this movie is very flat. There is some humor but there is little suspense and nothing that is going to stick out in most viewers' memories as anything incredible. This story is quite simple, actually, and its lack of sophistication makes it less enjoyable than it could have been. It seems like a movie directed at teenagers and Boston Red Sox fans more than any other groups.Performances are pretty good in this movie. This, added with the basic easy to follow plot, the likable characters, and the positive outcome of this film is enough to convince me to recommend it to potential viewers. It isn't a classic, but baseball fans will enjoy it nonetheless.
summary: How Much is Too Much When it Comes to Sports?

reviewText: Lindsey Meeks is climbing the corporate ladder and not looking for a relationship when she meets math teacher Ben Wrightman. She initially turns him down when he asks her out, but he persists and she agrees to go out with him, only to be stricken with food poisoning the day of their first date. She is smitten when Ben takes care of her and soon they are in a serious relationship. He seems to be perfect and Lindsey's friends urge her to be cautious since it seems strange that such a great guy is still single. Ben tells Lindsey that he's a huge Red Sox fan, and his apartment is full of Red Sox memorabilia, but it is not until baseball season starts that Lindsey realizes how fanatical Ben really is. He starts blowing Lindsey off, including a trip to Paris, for his beloved Red Sox and Lindsey, after a pregnancy scare, begins to question if she can stay in a relationship with him.  Soon Ben is torn between his love for the Red Sox and his love for Lindsey. Which will he choose?This is a cute romantic comedy, although I'm not sure if non-Red Sox fans will enjoy it as much as I did. It's not always laugh out loud funny, but there are some very funny moments. One particular scene, when Ben replays over and over again the scene of the ball going through Bill Buckner's leg, will make Red Sox fans laugh, while nodding sympathetically. Drew Barrymore and Jimmy Fallon are a cute couple, although he is more believable as a fun loving math teacher than she is as a driven career woman, mostly because it's never quite clear what she does or why she enjoys it so much. The Farrelly brothers had to change the ending of "Fever Pitch" when the Red Sox won the World Series and the ending feels rushed. It probably would have been a funnier ending if the Red Sox had lost.Viewers might be surprised that this is a straight romantic comedy by the Farrelly Brothers who are known more for their gross out jokes that make you laugh despite yourself. It's not nearly as funny as "There's Something About Mary" but it's still fun.

reviewText: At the core of this genial, by-the-numbers 2005 rom-com is a great idea - can a die-hard Boston Red Sox fan find a loving relationship with anything but his season tickets at Fenway Park? The Farrelly Brothers, Bobby and Peter, seem like the ideal choice for the potential comic hi-jinks, but it turns out to be a much softer, more predictable film than I hoped it would be. The plot focuses on Ben, a high school geometry teacher whose lifelong obsession with the Red Sox has obscured other aspects of his life. Through a field trip with a group of his students, he meets Lindsey, a successful executive at a firm that appears to specialize in statistical information. Given that Ben is a man-child and Lindsey has exalted expectations about men that need to be cut down a few pegs, they hit it off, especially after he nurses her through a strenuous bout with food poisoning. But things start to go rather awry when spring training begins. The rest is pretty formulaic until it hits a crisis point just before the Red Sox turn it around and become play-off contenders. Real-life events intrude upon the plot as we know the Red Sox won the 2004 World Series.Although he is convincing as a baseball fanatic, Jimmy Fallon is a bit too herky-jerky a screen persona to be entirely comfortable as a romantic lead. As Lindsey, Drew Barrymore, however, appears to be maturing into a fine comic actress. At her most idiosyncratic moments, she reminds me a bit of Jean Arthur. The rest of the cast is made up of ensembles of actors representing his and her friends and his Sox-based family in his ticket section at Fenway. Even with welcome faces like Ione Skye (where has she been since ""Say Anything"?) and Marissa Jaret Winokur of Broadway's "Hairspray" as two of Lindsey's friends and even JoBeth Williams as her mother, the characters remain pretty much generic filler. The predictable elements should come as no surprise since Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel, the team behind Billy Crystal's generic 1990's comedies, wrote the screenplay. Regardless, there is a certain charm that persists through the whole venture. The 2005 DVD has the usual assortment of extras - insightful though sometimes random commentary by the Farrellys on an alternate track, an eight-minute making-of short produced for the FOX network, two-minute featurettes on the love story angle and the Red Sox's comeback over the Yankees, thirteen deleted scenes of varying interest, a so-so gag reel and the theatrical trailer.
summary: Baseball Obsession Becomes a Relationship Hurdle in a Genial Rom-Com

That film had most of the same plot but no where near the same emotional punch and chemistry- and an ending that just sort of tailed off- almost an unfinished and certainly unpolished film.In stark contrast we have the remake starring Drew Barrymore.  The chemistry flows far better in this film, the story is tighter and actually makes far more sense. Substituting baseball was perfect (the title actually fits better).  The basic story line was preserved but the changes from Arsenal fan to 'God's most pathetic creature- a Redsox Fan' added a lot to the film.  The end of this film is also a little clunky but was made necessary by a completely unforeseen event- A championship.
summary: An Rarity- A remake that was better than the original

reviewText: This is a fun little "total package" film that appeals to both genders: it has a nice little love story along with Drew Barrymore taking on her first real grown-up role for the women, plus sports and the Farrelly Brothers' slapstick humor for the men compliments of the inside look at the demented little extended family started by "Nuff Ced" McGreevey and the Royal Rooters we lovingly call "Red Sox Nation."  This Americanization of the Nick Hornby novel brings you up to speed on the final quarter-century of the Curse Of The Bambino with astonishing accuracy, such as the CGIing of the Green Monster to what it looked like back in 1980 (a deleted scene even showed the old troughs in the Fenway men's room), the old Reverse Curve sign on Storrow Drive that was defaced to read "Reverse The Curse" and has since been cut down by Mitt Romney, and cameos by local hardcore fans such as Jessamy Finet and Stephen King.  I managed to catch the sneak preview of it the week before it opened, and happened to get the right crowd of fellow fans who wanted to relive Game 4; there were straight-out laughs at stuff like Ben's Yankee toilet paper, Troy's comment about Ted Williams rolling over in his freezer, Ben's use of a video of Buckner like it was a drug, and a round of applause when Foulke makes that famous underhanded toss.  The guy sitting next to me said to his girlfriend that he could see himself in the footage of the crowd at the rolling rally at the end.  The Curse Reversed Edition really isn't worth the extra cash, as it just extends the ending with additional playoff footage such as Manny and Millar doing some really interesting high-fives in the dugout.

reviewText: I've seen almost all of the Farrelly brothers' films and I have to say that "Fever Pitch" falls shorter than all of them.  But don't get me wrong, "Fever Pitch" is sufficient as a feel good, silly romance/comedy.  It drew quite a few laughs from me while I was watching it.  I watched it alone because my wife thought it would be "just another baseball movie."  It isn't just another baseball movie, however, it leans more toward the romantic side of comedy.The story revolves around Jimmy Fallon's character who is probably one of the most fanatical Boston Red Sox fans you could ever find.  He's a schoolteacher who falls for number-crunching Drew Barrymore.  They quickly fall for one another and Barrymore thinks it's cute when Fallon takes a knee and asks her to go to opening day with him.  She then quickly realizes just how fanatical Fallon is and the whole thing begins to affect their lovelife, her job, and her social life.  Eventually Fallon has to decide between Barrymore and the Red Sox.As always, Barrymore pulls her character off with style.  I still don't get what's so special about Fallon.  To me, he's just a second-rate Adam Sandler.  In fact, this film would have probably been funnier had Sandler taken the reins as the Sox fan.  Their are plenty of cameos on and off of the field, from modern day sluggers to old-timers.You don't have to enjoy baseball to like this film.  For that matter, you don't have to enjoy romantic comedies to enjoy this either.  It has just the right amount of both in it to keep most viewers occupied.  Also, this is based on Nick Hornby's "Fever Pitch" about a crazed football(soccer to us across the pond) fan.  This was adapted to film with the same title and Colin Firth as Fallon's character.  I haven't seen that version, but I'd love to since I really enjoy Firth's work.In closing, if you enjoy comedies with either romance OR baseball as a backdrop, you should take a gander at this film.  It isn't the best comedy out there, and nowhere near the best Farrelly flick around, but it is sufficient for a lazy afternoon with you wife or girlfriend.

reviewText: As a proud member of Red Sox Nation who will admit to shedding an actual tear or two when the Red Sox won the World Series in 2004, I'll admit that it didn't take much to get me out to see Fever Pitch.  But I actually enjoyed more than just the baseball footage...Drew Barrymore plays Lindsey Meeks, a dedicated and perpetuatlly-single businesswoman.  One day, she meets an average-guy schoolteacher, Ben (Jimmy Fallon).  Convinced by her friends that a normal guy with a normal life and a normal job might be just what she needs, Lindsey decides to give Ben a chance.  What follows is a whirlwind fairy-tale romance that seems too good to be true.  Then, one day, as the snow starts to thaw on the Boston Common, Ben makes a confession: he's a Red Sox fan.  If you've ever lived in Boston, you'll understand what this means.  Soon, Lindsey starts to realize that the Red Sox are more than just a baseball team.  They're her biggest competition.Fever Pitch is a must-own for any die-hard Sox fan.  But is it good enough for the non-Sox-fan viewer?  Perhaps not if you're a Yankees fan.  But Fever Pitch (loosely based on a Nick Hornby novel about what we in the States call soccer) is a cute chick flick for the rest of you. I wasn't the only one in the theater laughing to the point of tears-and, considering I now live in a place where people are usually either Reds fans or Indians fans, I think I can safely assume that you don't have to own a special edition World Series Johnny Damon T-shirt to enjoy Fever Pitch.  Those who don't get the Red Sox thing will think Ben and his friends are hilarious-and those who do get it will think it's funny `cuz it's true.

reviewText: When the Boston Red Sox lost game three of the American League Championship to the New York Yankees last October and it was duly noted by everybody covering the games that no team had ever come back from that sort of deficit to win a series in the history of baseball, it suddenly hit me that doing that was exactly how the Red Sox would "Reverse the Curse."  I had the same sort of metaphysical certainty for what was going to happen that I did in Game 7 of the 2001 World Series when Randy Johnson came in to pitch for Arizona, which meant that if the Diamondbacks came back in the bottom of the 9th, Johnson would be the first pitcher to win three World Series games in a long, long time.  Being a Yankees fan these were both bitter realizations, and my big regret is that I did not bet $100 for the Red Sox to win the World Series in four games the night this all hit me because I would still have been miserable, but I also would have been very rich.I did not watch the final two games of the AL Championship or the World Series (I knew what was going to happen, so what was the point?), which means I decided to watch "Fever Pitch" with some trepidation because I can live without salt being rubbed in the wounds.  But this 2005 comedy from the Farrelly Brother can be seen and enjoyed by fans of the Evil Empire as well as the Fenway Faithful, because what is important here is that Ben (Jimmy Fallon) is a baseball fan (which, you will call is short for "fanatic").  Because he is a Red Sox fan he is a long-suffering baseball fan.  He could be a Cub fan, but before 2004 the Chicago northsiders were still a distant second to the Red Sox when it came to the curse of Sisyphus department since Boston had lost a trio of World Series game sevens just in my lifetime, without bringing the "freakin'" tag team of Bucky Dent and Aaron Boone into the picture.  Besides, Ben has turned a wall of his living room into a replica of the Green Monster, which is way cool (bricks and vines like Wrigley Field would not be as cool and unless you try and do Monument Park what are you going to try and duplicate in your home to look like Yankee Stadium?).Ben is a math teacher in a grade school.  He meets Lindsey (Drew Barrymore) on a class field trip to her office and decides to ask her out.  It takes some effort to get to not having a first date, during which it is true that he looks, but he also does cleanup duty better left to the elves.  Lindsey is suitable impressed, but what she does not understand is that this is Winter Ben.  His season tickets to the Red Sox have not yet arrived, Fenway Park is covered in snow, and he has the time to focus attention on Lindsey.  The problem is going to be when Summer Ben blooms and Lindsey gets her first indication when she sees Spring Training Ben, who is like a maniac from another planet.  No wonder this guy is twenty-ten and unmarried.  But then so is Lindsey, so she has some issues too, just not as many as this guy.  Ben has dug himself in a massive hole with Lindsey, but then so have the Red Sox and you know how their season ended.Fallon is well suited to this role overall, although there are a few moments where he needs to act less and relax more.  His character is functionally insane so the point does not need to be overplayed to work.  But the problem here is more the script, which does not really think of Ben as being a real boy and allows mean-spirited jokes in the name of humor and at the expense of the character.  Barrymore is once again on perfect pitch and solidifies her position as the current queen of romantic comedy (see also, "50 First Dates").  She is smart, she is cute, and when she gets that hurt look in here eyes and that her voice sounds just so sad you want to take a baseball bat to the jerk who caused her that pain.  His Greek chorus consisting of his "summer family" at Fenway Park comes out ahead of her gal pal group, mainly because they have the grand litany of black days in Red Sox history as the text for their riffs.Yes, the ending of the film is a blatant example of having your cake and eating it too.  But do you really want a date movie where the women come out crying because of what Ben was willing to do to keep Lindsay and the men are cursing because of what Ben was willing to do to keep Lindsay?  Be sure to check out the bonus features that talk about how Barrymore and Fallon had to scramble to get to the final game of the World Series to take advantage of how baseball reality was once again taking a backseat to Hollywood fantasy.
summary: Can a die hard Boston Red Sox fan find happiness twice in one season?

reviewText: I'm a Red Sox fan and a sucker for romantic comedies, so I waited for the "Special Red Sox Collectors Edition" before even seeing the flick for the first time -- I knew I wanted to buy it. This review contrasts the two editions, with some minor comments about the movie at the end.Now I see I paid an extra $4 for the "Collector's Edition" over the regular DVD release for what amounts to about a minute of extra Red Sox highlights interpolated at the end. That's it. That's the only difference. That, my friends, is a rip-off from the marketing people, and a pretty crummy one.Not to say that as a DVD this isn't a very nice package. The gag reel is pretty funny. The directors' commentary and a couple of the featurettes are interesting enough. And the deleted scenes, frankly, make it into a better movie; I only wish they'd done a Director's cut and re-inserted the deleted scenes, because it makes the occasionally thin plot a lot fleshier. In particular, the deleted scene of Uncle Carl taking young Ben to his first game at Fenway is actually pretty wonderful, and great back story for why Ben is so addicted as an adult. It's a major weakness of Farrelly Brothers movies that they seem to cut for time what are often the best parts of the movies, resorting to the truly wretched device of voice-over narration to substitute for what would've been better done as actual story. "Me Myself and Irene" serves as the ultimate monument to this awful problem of trying to use voice-over narration to solve story problems, where script and editing problems could've been overcome with some attention before production was ever started. "Fever Pitch", fortunately, manages to stand up well enough even with the narration. It's just that it's more obvoiusly in watching the deleted scenes that this could've been raised from an enjoyable but somewhat fluffy movie to one with more of an edge -- both sweet and sour -- had they put them in the "original" movie.And, as I note, I did enjoy the movie -- the romantic comedy is relatively adult, and despite some glossing over of Ben and Lindsey's respective addictions to the Red Sox and the workplace, one does get a sense of adult motivations and a real relationship between the two. Jimmy Fallon, quite suprisingly, does an excellent job at walking a fine line here between not trying to be a film dreamboat (which he couldn't pull off) and avoiding being a complete moron in the loveable-moron school (which would've been unbelievable, given the Drew Barrymore character's sophistication.) In particular, he does a nice shift of gears from the sweet "winter Ben" to some over the top moments in the height of his Red Sox passion.One quibble, another thing that could've been fixed with the deleted scenes restored: you never quite get that verisimilitude of exactly what kind of dumb things us Red Sox fans get cranked up by -- arguing on the phone with, say, talk radio about managerial moves at 11 PM while your girlfriend lies naked and beckoning in bed, for instance. Still, good job on getting the essential passions on the table.But all that said, why on earth did I get charged an extra $4 for a few baseball highlights that do nothing to make the movie better? No good reason. If you like the movie or the idea of the movie, just buy the regular non-collectors' DVD edition. Even if you're a Red Sox diehard like me, no reason to shell out the extra money for the collectors' edition, because there's nothing to collect you won't also be able to get in the deluxe 2004 playoff DVD set of the games.
summary: Movie Gets 4 Stars, DVD Edition is a rip-off, though

reviewText: "Fever Pitch" is based on Nick Hornby's autobiographical novel of the same name, which chronicled the life of a fanatical British soccer fan. A more faithful film adaptation of the novel was made in 1997 in the UK. This latest version moves the action to Boston, USA, and changes the sport to baseball. Ben Wrightman (Jimmy Fallon) has been an obsessive Boston Red Sox fan since his Uncle Carl took him to a game at Fenway Park when he was 7 years old. Twenty-three years later, his enthusiasm for the Red Sox is undiminished. When he takes some of his geometry students to visit a professional who has applied mathematics to her career, Ben meets Lindsay Meeks (Drew Barrymore). Lindsay is an ambitious, successful corporate number-cruncher, in contrast to Ben's laid back, boyish school teacher, but the two awkwardly hit it off. Ben seems like the perfect man for Lindsay, but her friends wonder why such a nice guy is still single at age 30. With baseball season on the horizon, Lindsay is about to find out.Directors Peter and Bobby Farrelly are huge Red Sox fans themselves, so were a perfect fit for "Fever Pitch". Drew Barrymore and Jimmy Fallon both give appealing performances, making their characters' obsessions quirky, innocuous, and funny. Ben Wrightman captures Fallon's cute, disheveled, comedic charm. Barrymore has never looked better. So the biggest battle in a romantic comedy -appealing stars- is no battle here. Lindsay's trio of girlfriends deserves some mention. Ione Skye, Marissa Jaret Winokur, and KaDee Strickland are insightful and amusing as Lindsay's friends who are the first to wonder why Ben is still single. The women's conversations make good-natured fun of their competitiveness and suspicions, but strike me as very true to life. They probably add more to the film than their counterparts in Ben's trio of friends. I think "Fever Pitch" is a little too long for a romantic comedy. Some nonessential material could have been cut. But this is a fun film that revolves around the question of how much people should change for a relationship and how much they should expect the other person to change.  And it's likely to ring funny and true with sports fans and their mates.The DVD (20th Century Fox 2005): Bonus features include 13 deleted scenes, a gag reel (6 min.), a theatrical trailer (2  min.), 3 featurettes, and an audio commentary. In the "Love Triangle Internet Feature" (2 min.), Drew Barrymore talks about her character. "Break the Curse Internet Feature" (2  min.) is about the Red Sox winning streak in 2004, which coincided with the filming of the movie and how they were able to film at the World Series when the Red Sox won. "Making a Scene Fever Pitch" (8 minutes) features interviews with the Farrelly Brothers and their producers about the necessity of getting to St. Louis and filming at the World Series because it would cost so much to reproduce the scene if the Red Sox won. They tell the story of moving shooting from Toronto to St. Louis on the spur of the moment and borrowing one of Fox Sports' cameras to film in the stands. The audio commentary by Peter and Bobby Farrelly talks a little bit about the novel, locations, and filming, but focuses mostly on the cast and performances, including bit parts. Subtitles are available for the film in English and Spanish. Dubbing is available in French and Spanish.
summary: Appealing Romantic Comedy for Guys, Gals, and Sports Fans.

reviewText: Are the Farrelly Brothers growing up?  In the past they have made a string of utterly insane comedies that sometimes barely bordered on the edge of good taste (well, sometimes they did indeed cross over the edge), but here they have a movie that is tasteful from beginning to end.  That is not to say that it is bad for all that.  I found the first ten or fifteen minutes to be a bit on the slow side, and the vomit scenes unpleasant (I'm sorry, any guy who hung around an apartment while someone was being sick would not be taken a adorable and the act not as romantic, but all in all more than a little weird, especially the staying on the couch overnight part), but after it got underway, I enjoyed this quite a bit.This is actually a pretty accurate picture of what relationships are like:  flawed and filled with compromise.  The movies all-too-often portray romance as if it were all a question of waiting for the perfect person, while in fact it is a question of waiting for an imperfect person.  The issue in FEVER PITCH is whether one can have a relationship with someone who is overall pretty decent, but has an overwhelming obsession in their life.  In this case, can Lindsey manage a relationship with Ben, who is a really nice guy except for his utter obsession with the Boston Red Sox, an obsession that might top his love for her?  I really liked this whole idea of imperfect people forcing themselves to make compromises to find--as the self-help book tells us--someone to love instead of someone perfect.The movie was pretty funny throughout, not one of the funniest you'll see, but enough to be consistently entertaining.  I have always liked Drew Barrymore and loved seeing her in this as in her previous films (though I didn't like the red hair).  I have always hated Jimmy Fallon (sorry, but its true) and while I'm not anxious to search out his next movie, I didn't dislike him in this like I expected to.  I do think the movie would have been strengthened by a stronger actor in his role, but he didn't kill the film by any stretch of the imagination.  I really enjoyed all the location shots in the film, not just in Fenway (my second favorite MLB ballpark after my beloved Wrigley Field, only two blocks from my apartment) but in Boston as a whole.All in all, this was a pretty decent romantic comedy.  It also goes down as probably the best romantic baseball movie ever made.  OK, there isn't a lot of competition in that category, but there you go.  In closing, I would like add that I actually prefer this to the British film starring Colin Firth that was also based on the Nick Hornby novel FEVER PITCH.  Like HIGH FIDELITY, Hornby's novel translates exceptionally well from a British to an American context.
summary: A thoroughly enjoyable romantic comedy with a twist

reviewText: The funny sports fanatic is the cynic who loves his team so much he can insult it profanely and relentlessly - the lovable, intelligent fan, winner or loser. He is generally not a complete idiot, he does not generally own 9,000 pieces of memorabilia or cover his ears at a restaurant so he won't know who won last night's baseball game. That's the annoying sports fanatic."Fever Pitch" gives us the second fan, Ben (Jimmy Fallon), junior high math teacher goofball follower of the Boston Red Sox. He's thirty going on fourteen, thoughtful enough, a little off in his priorities, and generally not a funny guy. Girls may very well find him funny, and the portrayal of his fanaticism accurate. But, then, they're girls. This is probably what they think most guys are like with sports. The female equivalent to Ben would be a shopaholic riding around *inside* the cart at Shopko.Directed by Peter and Bobby Farrelly, the movie is really more about Lindsey (producer Drew Barrymore) a thirtysomething engineer who meets Ben when he brings some students to her firm. On a dare Ben asks Lindsey out and plays nice through their winter courtship, helping Lindsey keep her jackal pack of gossipy, doubting friends at bay.Then baseball season begins, and Ben turns down a trip to Lindsey's parents to go scout his team at spring training. Later he rejects a weekend in Paris to see a Sox game. The inevitable conflicts ensue. Ben has the team. Lindsey has her job. Cue up the typical peaks, valleys and misunderstandings of a romantic comedy. Fallon and Barrymore has fair chemistry, although Barrymore is cuter than Fallon is anything. Ben is a bore, a sheepish, unimpressive geek with an immature wardrobe and childlike view of life. Lindsey's pretty forgiving, really, and the movie fudges a bit by having Ben break her heart in a key scene instead of simply allowing Lindsey to level him with a hard gaze and tell him to grow up.It'd be more forgivable if "Fever Pitch" seemed to know much about the Red Sox, or baseball. The script by Lowell Ganz and Babaloo Mandel doesn't go there. Yes, Ben recounts the Sox' unfortunate history after trading Babe Ruth in 1919. But he doesn't express any love for the sport - other than saying it's simple, which is not the same as saying it's sublime - never declares a favorite player, never jeers an opposing team. And Fallon, as the hired hand - it's Barrymore's production remember - does what he's told. It's a guy's flick cut off at the stirrups.
summary: A chick flick about a sports fanatic? Yep, pretty much.

And this year it seems Boston Red Sox is going to break the curse.There are lots of funny moments (without gross-out gags you have seen in Farrelly Brothers who directed this film), and Drew Barrymore is always great in romantic comedy. Jimmy Fallon is also very good as Ben, and what is remarkable about his character is that he didn't rely on caricature, creating the three-dimensional character of Ben.To me, one disappointing thing about `Fever Pitch' is its concluding chapters, which are not only predictable (OK, I can live with that), but also are told too hurriedly. The film's dramatic ending about the story of Lindsey and Ben needs more time and subtle treatment. (It is changed because of the Red Sox's winning at the World Series.) And though I know very well that this is no longer Nick Hornby, the film could have provided some more wit or insightful observation about the sports fans.As romantic comedy the film is a success thanks to the two leads. I enjoyed watching lovely Drew Barrymore in `Fever Pitch,' thinking at the same time: What kind of guy doesn't prefer spending time with Lindsey? But some people actually don't; as the film shows, they prefer watching their team beat the rival even though they sense that as one kid quietly says to Ben, the team may not "love back." But you know for sure no matter what happens, Drew's Lindsey would love back. This is one of the established rules of sweet, cute and (sorry but) conventional romantic comedy, which `Fever Pitch' is.
summary: A Double, If Not a Home Run, Thanks to the Two Leads

reviewText: There are, to be sure, more than a few reasons to dislike this movie.  It's cheesy as all get-up, as sappy as maple syrup, and the final scene is so unbelievable as to be laughable.  Yet, at least for me, "Fever Pitch" works because of one factor: the ability to describe the life of a baseball die-hard.For a basic plot summary, this movie tells the love story of Ben (Jimmy Fallon) and Lindsey (Drew Barrymore).  Ben, a school teacher with a Boston Red Sox obsession and Lindsey, a confident career-woman, play off each other's personas in typical rom-com format.Had this movie not dealt with baseball, I probably wouldn't have had anything to do with it.  At its core, it is true rom-com through and through.  However, being a huge baseball fan, I could really relate to Fallon's character.  The entire film really nails baseball fanaticism.  Whether it is Ben getting down on one knee to reveal...a ticket to Opening Day, or charting out pitching schedules to make sure he never misses Pedro Martinez, Fallon's antics are very relatable to the hardball diehards.  Over the top, yes, but springing from a kernel of real sports fanaticism.Another "luck" factor to this movie is that it follows the 2004 Boston Red Sox, perhaps the most endearing baseball team so far this millennium.  Every baseball fan (from the Bronx to the Bay) remembers that fantastic run, so this movie (by sheer luck) re-captures that magic every time it is played.Overall, "Fever Pitch" is a traditional romantic comedy that just happens to be something more for fans of the'04 Red Sox or baseball fanatics in general.  It isn't perfect, but it is quite entertaining and will get watched more than once a year if in your collection.
summary: The (Romantic) Life Of A Baseball Fanatic
